Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a Three-Dimensional Multi-Wavelength Raman Spectrometer for the Nanotechnology Characterization

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) award supports acquisition of a Raman spectroscopy system that is integrated with an atomic force microscope, capable of three-dimensional structural and Raman mapping, capable of cryogenic to high temperature operation (77 ? 1,800 K), outfitted with five different wavelengths for Raman probing, and aligned with an additional integrated path for a pump laser. The Raman spectroscopy system will significantly impact and enable a wide range of research projects, including nanomaterial synthesis and assembly, carbon detection and identification, and chemical and biological sensing. It will also play an important role in the validation of computational nanoscience initiatives. The instrument will also advance the understanding of Raman processes at ultra-high temperatures and extreme chemical environments, along with furthering the field of integrated Raman-atomic force microscopy processes and tip-enhanced Raman scattering

Raman spectroscopy is a a powerful technique for characterizing frequencies, energies, and fingerprints of matter. This instrument will be housed in Wilsdorf Hall, a recently completed facility dedicated to cutting-edge, multidisciplinary research and actively managed, operated, and supported under the existing infrastructure of the Nanoscale Materials Characterization Facility (NMCF) at the University of Virginia. Existing research thrusts that will utilize the instrument are interdisciplinary, connecting various departments in the Engineering School and the College of Arts and Sciences, and range from basic science and materials discovery to contaminant detection in water supplies. The instrument will be integrated into a combination of classroom and laboratory discussions and activities in multiple classes at both the undergraduate and graduate levels, spanning six disciplines, thus impacting a diverse audience. The use of this instrument will also be encouraged in existing REU and RET programs, which target underrepresented groups and expose them to cutting edge research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The kinematic and vibrational states of atoms and molecules dictate the restrictive and resistive transport processes in all phases of media. These atomic and molecular states are unique to each type of material or combination of materials. The ever-present need to manufacture and create devices, sensors, and applications with length scales on the characteristic transport dimensions of atoms and molecules has given rise to challenges of detection, characterization, and thermal mitigation of the media in the application. As an example, in non-metallic solids, quantized vibrational states of atoms (phonons) govern heat transfer; these atomic vibrations are the primary resistance in applications ranging from solar and electrical energy conversion devices to nanoelectronic computing. The ability to detect the interaction of phonon modes in the nanomaterials comprising these aforementioned devices has given rise to methods of thermal mitigation and characterization that have advanced and progressed these applications.

Clearly, the ability to directly probe the energetic states of atoms and molecules in various phases of media will benefit a wide array of fields and applications in technologies ranging from the nano- to meso-scale.  One of the best well-known tools for directly probing the energetic vibrational states in all phases of media is Raman spectroscopy. In most applications of modern Raman spectroscopy, a sample is illuminated with a coherent laser source. The laser light then interacts with molecular vibrations, phonons, or other excitations in the material causing the laser energy to be shifted up or down based on the energy of the excitation in the system. The resultant energy shift of the photons emanating from the material is related to the energy of the excited kinematic states in the material. In addition, the properties of the resulting Raman shifted photons (i.e., laser intensity and line width) give insight into the collision rates and lifetimes of the excited states. In short, Raman spectroscopy offers a direct measure of the energy states and interaction times in matter. Raman spectroscopy is also particularly robust, as spectra can be obtained from nearly all samples containing true molecular interactions.

This proposed instrumentation program enabled the acquisition of a Raman spectroscopy system that is integrated with an atomic force microscope, capable of three-dimensional structural and Raman mapping, high temperature operation, and five different wavelengths for Raman probing.  Existing research thrusts that have routinely utilized this proposed facility are interdisciplinary, connecting 3 departments in the Engineering School and the Physics and Chemistry Departments straddling research areas of carbon detection, nanostructure characterization, chemical and biological sensing, and computational validation.

Over the lifetime of this program, 28 graduate students were trained on this equipment from 13 different groups in 5 different departments in both the School of Engineering and Applied Sciences and the College of Arts and Sciences at U.Va. Furthermore, this equipment was utilized by a professor of Physics from James Madison University who has been training new undergraduates on this system. The tremendous impact of this collaborative project that it has on James Madison University (JMU) undergraduate students is difficult to underestimate, taking into account the wealth of new information and knowledge to which the JMU students are exposed. The JMU undergraduate students had participated and contributed to the ongoing experiments at UVA that are aligned with the goals of Dr. Hopkins' group centered around the Raman spectrometer. In addition, they get exposed to graduate level research and what life is like in graduate school, as JMU Physics is an undergraduate only program.

Over the lifetime of this program, the data and results generated via this Raman system have resulted in 21 papers and 33 talks.
